Hi, just a friendly botanist here. You have a lot of critical but common errors in this video (it is okay, you are clearly not trained in botany, which is common). Here is a short list:  -CO2 doesn't turn into O2, H2O does -gymnosperms and angiosperms also descendants of initial green algae--Plantae is monophyletic -all plants need water for reproduction, was actually a major evolutionary pressure for the pollen tube & ovules -Spanish moss is not a lichen, but rather a flowering plant -alternation of generations description is a mess; alternation of generations is an outdated term used to over simplify the concept of haplodiplonticity, which is based on cell ploidy and multicellularity and not size or independence of the resulting cells/tissues/plant bodies. -SPORES ARE NOT DIPLOID; this is really critical -You never define where meiosis happens in the life cycle; this contributes to your spore error; sexual life cycles are defined by meiosis and fertilization--you cannot teach them adequately without including both -POLLEN IS NOT A GAMETE; it is actually a spore, it germinates via mitosis into a multicellular haploid body that then produces sperm (gamete) via mitosis -compare and contrast of vascular to non-vascular plants is a mess because all the understanding of plant life cycles is based off of misconceptions (see above) and therefore cannot be correctly applied to the vascular plants, which also display full haplodiplonticity or "alternation of generations."  Normally your videos are very good, especially the cellular processes series, and I use them frequently when I teach. This video, however, I save for my advanced botany students so that I can use it to test their skills of evaluation.

The gametophyte (the first generation) reproduces sexually with eggs and sperm. The gametes (from the gametophyte) go through fertilization and become zygotes (diploids). These zygotes (2n) go through mitosis to form Sporophytes (diploids). The sporophytes go through meiosis to produce haploid spores (n). Like, it states in the video, the sporophyte remains attached to the parent gametophyte for nutrients. Then once its spores disperse and generate the cycle starts over again.  So basically, the gametophyte is the first generation. Reproduction: sexual    The sporophyte is the second generation. Reproduction: asexual

+Mercedes Cordoway The algae from the phylum Charophyta have a haplontic life cycle, meaning that there is a macroscopic gametofite wich produces antheridia or archegonia, and in these two, gametes are formed (sperm and the egg) . After fertilization the zygote divides meiotically (this life cycle is also known as zygotic meiosis), then the cells resulting from this division will give rise to another gametophyte and the cycle goes on again.   But the relationship between the two organisms (charophyta and bryophytes) is not due to the life cycle but rather to the similarities in the reproductive structures, more specifically a cover of somatic cells in the gametangia.  Another simillarity are the pigments (this indicates chloroplast filogenetic relation) wich are in both organisms Chl "a" and "b". They also have similarities in the habitat, both are from fresh water ecosistems and can survive out of the water.   The change in the life cycle can be due to environmental stress. The alternation of generation appears also on various types of brown algae, and in red algae, so, the life cycle ist a very good character to relate filogenetically two organisms

So alternation of generations is when there are two distinct "versions" of a species, which alternate. The "first" one (Obviously neither comes "before" the other.) is the gametophyte, it reproduces sexually, giving rise to the next generation, the sporophyte.
